awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Engaging Undergraduates in STEM using Drosophila Behavioural Genetics (EUSTEM-DaBuGs TIP)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students in STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The project at North Carolina Central University (NCCU) will develop an integrated undergraduate education, training, and research initiative in behavioral genetics and engineering design by creating Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) in two courses: a sophomore elective and a junior required course. The infusion of cross-disciplinary CUREs into two biology courses, development of a cross-disciplinary summer research experience and the strengthening of the existing relationships with surrounding Research institutions will have a direct impact on students and faculty at NCCU. The project will facilitate student retention and motivate underrepresented minority students (URM) to pursue graduate studies and/or careers in STEM disciplines.

The overall goal of the project is to educate, train, and provide cross-disciplinary research experiences to URM students at NCCU; thus, facilitating a successful undergraduate matriculation within STEM majors and into graduate programs at nearby Research-1 institutions (Duke, UNC-Chapel Hill and NC State University). The specific goals are:  1) to infuse real-world research experiences including engineering design challenges and measuring Drosophila Behaviours and relating these behaviors to Genetics (DaBuGs) through two CURE courses and 2) to have sophomore/junior-level research fellows participate in a cross-disciplinary, summer research experience tied to a research mentoring course with the primary goal of completing authentic research and design projects begun in the two CURE courses. The long-term goal is to create an integrated engineering and DaBuGs education, training, and research initiative at NCCU. This is expected to increase student performance and enthusiasm in STEM, and expose URM students to engineering design and behavioral research through the sophomore- and junior-level biology CUREs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Introduction.

To meet the educational needs of 21st Century STEM careers, interdisciplinary educational programs need to be developed and accessible to all demographics including Underrepresented Minority (URM) students. The long-term goal of the project is to begin to establish a cross-disciplinary training program in the emerging biological science field of behavioral genetics and the burgeoning 3+2 training program in engineering design at the oldest, public Historically Black College or University (HBCU) in the country.

How do we begin to create a bridge for undergraduate students attending HBCUs to institutions research-intensive institutions throughout the country?  We assembled the scaffold by infusing two biology-based courses with introductory engineering design theory and practice.  Additionally, we designed an innovative 6-week multi-disciplinary summer internship as described in the initial grant application objectives:

Objective 1: To provide students with real-world engineering design challenges and behavioral genetics research experiences through a multi-faceted infusion of Drosophila Behavioural Genetics (DaBuGs) CUREs into two courses:

  1. A newly created sophomore-level Biology elective, honors CURE course (year 1)
  2. CURE infusion of the teaching lab of a required, junior-level Genetics course (year 2).

Objective 2: To enhance student`s intrinsic motivation to pursue behavioral genetics and engineering through a DaBuGs Summer Internship Program (SIP), wherein DaBuGs Research Fellows, trained in the above courses, apply for 1-4 positions in a summer research programs to be co-mentored by the Biology PI, the Fab Lab co-PI and the Physics co-PI in a cross-disciplinary, summer, independent research course experience with the primary goal of completing authentic research and engineering design projects initiated in the Objective 1 CURE courses. (Years 1-3).

Intellectual Merit

Part of the attraction of the project is that the bench assays measured alcohol-induced behaviors in fruit flies. As alcohol-induced behaviors are familiar to students, they can pull from their real-world observations to formulate hypotheses, design experiments, and collect data on their observations.  Additionally, the targeted infused courses introduced TinkerCAD.an engineering software program to students.  While students in the Genetics course designed and fabricated 3D objects to illustrate an aspect of their semester long family heritage project (molecules, diseased organs, gene mutations), students in the newly developed, DaBuGs CURE and the 6-week summer internship created devices that could measure the fruit fly behavior.

While the Covid-19 Pandemic impeded the in-person hands-on delivery during implementation, we were encouraged those assessments indicated that students in both infused courses made knowledge gains (+7% in Genetics lab and +24% in DaBuGs course) in the field of behavioral genetics. Additionally, we observed increases in the students’ ability to design experiments (+13.6% gain in Genetics and +30.3% gain in the DaBuGs course).  The instructors found that the cloud based TinkerCAD program and ‘low’ to ‘no’ contact approaches to meeting with students provided students with learning gains during these authentic, real-world research experiences.

One over-arching goal is to increase the matriculation of Underrepresented Minority (URM) undergraduate students into STEM graduate programs. We are pleased that 27 of the 31 in DaBuGs students have chosen research careers (42%) and 4 have attended or plan to attend master’s or doctoral programs (26%).

Broader Impacts

The grant had aimed to engage between 100-167 Underrepresented Minority (URM) undergraduate students in at least 1 of the 2 targeted infused courses, 10 URM students in the summer internship, and to support 2 URM master’s students in their authentic research projects. All these targets were hit with a total of 145 URM students that participated in at least one of the two infused courses; 11 students participated in the summer internship and 4 master’s students were supported in their research: two of which have completed their thesis work and two more will complete theirs by 2024. Dissemination of project results has taken many forms including 12 undergraduate posters at 4 regional meetings (NC Academy of Sciences (NCAS), State of North Carolina Creativity and Research Symposiums (SNCURCS), Graduate and Undergraduate Research Symposium (GURS) in North Carolina and at the Society for Developmental Biology – Mid-Atlantic meeting at Princeton University, New Jersey).  Additionally, the Principal Investigator (P.I.) of the grant presented oral posters at 2 regional meetings (Project Kaleidoscope (PKAL) in Massachusetts and Association for Southeastern Biologists in Little Rock, Arkansas). Furthermore, the P.I. presented 2 workshops and 3 oral posters at 4 national meetings (the Association for Biology Laboratory Education (ABLE), two meetings of the AAAS/HBCU-UP-CREST/P.I.-P.D. Meeting in Washington, D.C, and at the American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) in Minneapolis, MN).  Two manuscripts in Advances in Biology Laboratory Education (ABLE) and the ASEE Conference Journal have been published.  Finally, three more manuscripts reporting the findings of this grant will be submitted to STEM Education Research journals and published no later than mid-2024.
